did.abstract: Betty Bressi was a teacher and artist who was recruited to teach in camps in which Japanese Americans were incarcerated during World War II. Bressi taught in the Jerome War Relocation Center in Arkansas, although her time at the facility ended before World War II concluded. The Betty Bressi Papers (dated 1981-2004) consist of materials created and collected by Bressi documenting her sustained interest in issues surrounding Japanese American incarceration during World War II, Japanese American activism, and the redress movement. Materials include newspaper and magazine articles that document the trajectory of the redress movement, media portrayals of Japanese American activism, and public discourse concerning the concept of reparations. The collection also includes programs and playbills from theatrical productions by the Pan Asian Repertory Theatre. The collection provides rare documentation from white actors involved in the incarceration of Japanese Americans, which is recounted through Bressi's unpublished memoir "Teaching at Jerome Relocation Center." Bressi's active collecting of newspaper coverage of the redress movement, her correspondence with editors regarding their coverage of Japanese American incarceration, and her sustained contact with Madeleine Sugimoto (one of her students at Jerome) and her father, artist Henry Sugimoto, reflects the impact of her experiences on her perspectives after World War II.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Betty Bressi Papers (dated 1981-2004) consist of materials created and collected by Bressi documenting her sustained interest in issues surrounding Japanese American incarceration during World War II, Japanese American activism, and the redress movement. Materials include newspaper and magazine articles that document the trajectory of the redress movement, media portrayals of Japanese American activism, and public discourse concerning the concept of reparations. The collection also includes programs and playbills from theatrical productions by the Pan Asian Repertory Theatre. The collection provides rare documentation from white actors involved in the incarceration of Japanese Americans, which is recounted through Bressi's unpublished memoir "Teaching at Jerome Relocation Center." Bressi's active collecting of newspaper coverage of the redress movement, her correspondence with editors regarding their coverage of Japanese American incarceration, and her sustained contact with Madeleine Sugimoto (one of her students at Jerome) and her father, artist Henry Sugimoto, reflects the impact of her experiences on her perspectives after World War II. Included in the collection is a copy of a print that Sugimoto gifted to her, as well as a copy of a painting she herself made of Jerome.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Susan Visconti, Bressi's niece, in July 2025; the accession number associated with this gift is 2025.076.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: One folder of newspaper clippings from the Betty Bressi Papers was identified as being located in the archives office of the Asian/Pacific/American Institute at NYU in 2023. There is no information about the provenance of these materials or how or why they were transferred to NYU. After being contacted by A/P/A, Susan Visconti, Bressi's niece, reviewed her aunt's possessions for related materials that were later transferred to NYU.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Betty Bressi (died 2014) was a teacher and artist. As a student at St. Joseph's College, studying towards a degree in education, she was recruited to teach in camps in which Japanese Americans were incarcerated during World War II. Bressi taught in the Jerome War Relocation Center in Arkansas, although her time at the facility ended before World War II concluded. Bressi never forgot her time spent at the Jerome camp, and remained invested in issues concerning Japanese American activism and the redress movement.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact NYU Special Collections (special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596) with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
